headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Welcome to the Southwest Airlines Fourth Quarter 2009 Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] We have on the call today Gary Kelly, Southwest's Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Laura Wright, the company's Senior Vice President, Financ
componenttext: Welcome to the Southwest Airlines Fourth Quarter 2009 Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] We have on the call today Gary Kelly, Southwest's Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Laura Wright, the company's Senior Vice President, Finance and Chief Financial Officer.Before we get started, please be advised that this call will include forward-looking statements. Because these statements are based on the company's current intent, expectations and projections, they are not guarantees of future performance and a variety of factors could cause actual results to differ materially. This call will also include references to non-GAAP results. Therefore, please see our earnings press release in the Investor Relations section of our website at www.southwest.com for further information regarding our forward-looking statements and for a reconciliation of our non-GAAP results to our GAAP results. At this time, I would like to turn the call over to Gary Kelly for opening remarks. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Marvin. Thanks, everyone, for joining us. Obviously, we are -- at the end of this roller coaster year, we are delighted to be able to report that our profitability string is intact and to be able to report even a very modest profit in this environ
componenttext: Thanks, Marvin. Thanks, everyone, for joining us. Obviously, we are -- at the end of this roller coaster year, we are delighted to be able to report that our profitability string is intact and to be able to report even a very modest profit in this environment, I think, is a huge accomplishment. But I'm very proud of our employees. It's been a real roller coaster. A lot of changes, a lot of challenges, but I think they more than prove that they are up to the task. The earnings for the fourth quarter to start there were $74 million on a non-GAAP basis and that's $0.10 a share better than a year ago, better than the Wall Street estimate and certainly better than what we thought six, eight months ago.For the full year, we did $143 million in earnings, again on a non-GAAP basis. That's $0.19 a share down from the 2008 levels, but certainly understandable given the very challenging economy that we faced in 2009. A lot of remarkable things about the fourth quarter though. The fourth quarter, at least to the best of my recollection, has never been the best quarter in a year and this year, it was by far, it was the best unit revenue performance of the year, but that means that we set an all-time record in terms of quarterly unit revenue in the fourth quarter of a recession. And that is remarkable indeed. And you might say it's because we adjusted our capacity but that doesn't explain it because their traffic was actually up and we added record level of traffic for a fourth quarter and that's despite a near 80%  drop in our capacity. It's probably  not too surprising to you than the sign that we also had a  record load factor performance for the fourth quarter as we did for the full year. So a number of very strong metrics, if you will, measuring our revenue performance. And so we're just delighted all the way around. And it took -- It's not just our Marketing department, not just our Schedule Planning department, not just Operations, not just Revenue Management. It took literally every employee at Southwest Airlines to produce those kinds of results and make the kinds of changes that we did in 2009.At this point, we have strong bookings in place for the balance of the quarter. Here in the first quarter of '10, January, February, March bookings looked really good. Just glancing at yesterday's bookings this morning, we had another strong day yesterday. The trend so far in January, Laura will speak to in a minute, but we're very pleased with the trends that we're seeing so far in 2010.Just to give you a very quick recap on some of the things that we did in 2009 to boost our revenue, I think first and foremost was the focus on our very high quality operation. We've had the best on-time performance that we've seen in years. We're turning out some of the best baggage handling numbers that we have ever had in our history. And once again, we're leading the industry in the fewest customer complaints. So just a very, very high quality operation, once again, despite all of the aggressive changes that took place. The other again, first and foremost, steps that we took, is we just focused on our Low Fare Brand. And we had some very successful, aggressive fare sales. We've launched a series of advertising campaigns that really drive home what we stand for and of course, we're all very proud of our Bags Fly Free Campaign. You can't find a customer now who isn't aware that Southwest doesn't charge for bags and we're getting a lot of credit for that and I think that course is certainly one of the reasons that we're seeing a pretty significant share shift to Southwest Airlines. Our capacity is down but our traffic is up.We had a number of aggressive changes to the schedule this year. I've already mentioned our fare sales. We introduced our EarlyBird product, we now carry  [ph] (15:54) pets, we added a three very large cities to our route network, launching Milwaukee as our fourth city late in the year. We've seen huge gains in our Denver market. And Denver in August of this year will be up to 144 daily departures, making it the fifth largest city in our route network and by far, the most successful new city we've ever had. And we also have some very nice opportunities that are unfolding in St. Louis.The sequential improvement that we've seen in our business in the fourth quarter is very broad, and that is compared primarily, let's say, to the second quarter earlier this year. But I do think it's fair to say that our short-haul markets are still lagging behind some of the other markets and I would also attribute that to a still a softness in business travel. And then finally, before I turn it over to Laura, I just want to make appointment very -- even on the earnings weren't at record levels for the year, we did have a very respectable fourth quarter earnings performance. If you compare it to the last five years, it's not our best but it ain't bad. But I think more importantly for the year, we had near $1 billion in operating cash flow that was generated and to be able to do that in a recessionary environment, we have already managed our capital spending much lower, was again just a very, very encouraging sign. So it's been a very gratifying year for us. And I think without a doubt, we're very, very confident about how we think about our future. So with that, I would just like to turn it over to Ms. Laura Wright, our Chief Financial Officer.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Gary, and good morning, everyone. We're very pleased to report a profit for the fourth quarter and the full year. Our fourth quarter net income of $116 million included a net gain of $42 million relating to non-cash, market-to-market and other
componenttext: Thank you, Gary, and good morning, everyone. We're very pleased to report a profit for the fourth quarter and the full year. Our fourth quarter net income of $116 million included a net gain of $42 million relating to non-cash, market-to-market and other items associated with SFAS 133. Excluding these special items, our fourth quarter net income was $74 million or $0.10 per diluted share, which was far better than we thought possible just months ago and easily exceeded Wall Street's mean estimate of $0.07 per diluted share.Our fourth quarter revenue results were outstanding and our unit revenue trends have continued to outperform the industry. For the fourth quarter, our operating unit revenues were up 7.4% year-over-year. We continue to gain market share with our traffic up over 5% in the quarter despite an almost 8% reduction in our capacity. We posted monthly record load factors beginning with July and ended the year strong with the fourth quarter record performance of 77.3%, which was up almost 10 points from a year ago. This surpassed a long record, our record performance is 70.3% from the fourth quarter of 2006.In July, we launched a WOW! Sale for travel post-Labor Day through mid-November. It set all-time booking records and helped drive our load factors during this period to new highs. We're also seeing a positive customer reaction to our Bags Fly Free campaign and as a result, our year-over-year unit revenue comparisons were favorable in October, November and December. November and December's year-over-year unit revenue comparisons were impacted by the Thanksgiving shift, which did sit on  November resin [ph] (19:35) between one and two percentage points. For the two months combined, our unit revenues were up almost 8% compared to November and December of 2008.Strong bookings and year-over-year unit revenue trends are continuing into 2010 and month to date, our January passenger resin [ph] (19:54) is estimated to have increased between 14% and 15% year-over-year. I do keep in mind that our January capacity is estimated to be down almost 7% compared to a 4% to 5% reduction in February and March, which will make our comparisons a little more difficult in the February and March time periodBased on our full fare mix, we believe that our full fare business traffic has stabilized but we are definitely not back to pre-recession levels and for the fourth quarter of 2009, our full fare mix was 18%. Again, our employees have done an extraordinary job responding to the weak demand environment and we couldn't be more pleased with their efforts. As Gary mentioned, we launched a number of new revenue initiatives during the year. Although unplanned, we introduced our new Pet Fare, our Unaccompanied Minor charge, EarlyBird Check-in and we're very pleased with the revenue contribution of these initiatives. Our EarlyBird revenues, which are included in other revenues were approximately $13 million in the fourth quarter. Our Business Select revenue in the fourth quarter held steady at about $18 million and for the full year with $72 million. In addition to that, we generated over $10 million in other revenues for our new Pet Fare, Unaccompanied Minor charges and excess heavy bag fees.Our schedule optimization efforts has been a huge success and was significantly benefiting from our capacity cuts and the realignment of our network. We've eliminated approximately 10% of our flights that were unprofitable over the last year and we kept our fleet flat because of weak travel demand. Our own capacity cuts, the successful schedule optimization, represented the majority of our 7.4% year-over-year RASM increase. Through our optimization efforts, we were able to open Minneapolis/St. Paul, New York LaGuardia, Boston Logan and Milwaukee as well as coexisting markets such as Denver and St. Louis. We continue to advance our revenue management structure and techniques and we're very pleased with the results of the steps we took late in the third quarter to restructure our fares to provide an array of low-fare options that better respond to the impact the recession has had on demand. The fourth quarter revenue impact was greater than expected and produced tens of million in incremental revenue for the quarter.We've also upgraded www.southwest.com and are seeing higher book-to-look rates and higher average fares from our shoppers. With respect to freight and other revenues, our freight revenues were down about 16% year-over-year due to the weak economy. We expect our freight revenues for the first quarter of 2010 to be in line with our fourth quarter 2009 freight revenues. Our other revenues were up significantly year-over-year in the fourth quarter and as I mentioned before, the ancillary revenues from Pets, UMs, early birds and bags combined for almost $25 million during the quarter. We expect a strong year-over-year improvement in our other revenues to continue into the first quarter of 2010.Turning to our fourth quarter cost performance. Our fourth quarter operating expenses, excluding special items, decreased 2.7% versus fourth quarter of last year, largely due to lower fuel costs. Our economic fuel cost decreased 3.1% to $2.20 per gallon for the quarter, which was slightly better than we anticipated. Fuel prices remain volatile and we continue to actively manage our portfolio and our associated premium costs. We recently restructured our 2010 fuel hedge portfolio and we're currently about 50% hedged in 2010 at prices up to about $100 per barrel. We recently sold call options, which decreased our protection to 20% if the market prices settle in the $100 to $120 per barrel range and we added another layer of purchase call options to provide catastrophic protection at levels above $120, which increases our protection to approximately 40% hedged if market prices exceed $120.Our 2010 hedged portfolio includes a combination of swaps, callers, call options and call spreads. The premium costs associated with our 2010 fuel hedge portfolio, which are recorded below the line in other gains and losses were estimated to be approximately $115 million in 2010 or about $30 million per quarter, which is less than the $148 million spent in 2009. Based on current market prices, we're estimating our first quarter 2010 fuel costs including fuel taxes, but excluding premiums, to be in the $2.35 per gallon range. Our first quarter 2010 fuel price estimates includes a $0.10 per gallon hedge penalty based on current market prices. This has significantly improved from the $0.17 penalty at the time we de-hedged in the fourth quarter of 2008.To provide you with some sensitivity with respect to our first quarter 2010 fuel hedge, if first quarter prices drop an average $60 per barrel for the quarter, our hedging penalty increases to about $0.24 per gallon as the current gains we have in the hedges placed in 2009 are reduced and no longer offset the loss from the 2008 de-hedging. If first quarter prices rise in average $95 per barrel for the quarter, we would expect to have a $0.09 per gallon hedging benefit.Volatility mix is quite difficult to provide precise [ph] (26:18) guidance for 2010, however, our best touch points based on the current forward prices and our existing hedge portfolio is in the $2.30 to $2.35 per gallon range, which is about $0.10 above current market prices. For 2011, we currently have about 40% our estimated fuel consumption hedged with the majority using callers and we have modest positions in place for 2012 and 2013. As of two days ago, the total net liability of our current steel hedge portfolio was around $500 million.Excluding fuel and special items, our unit costs were up 8.6% year-over-year to $7.45. This performance was in line with our expectations and slightly under our guidance of $7.5. One of the drivers of the increase in our unit cost was our reduction in capacity, which was down 7.7% in the quarter. The remaining is inflationary pressures in such areas as salaries, wages and airport costs. Based on current cost trends and headwinds from lower first quarter capacity, we currently estimate our first quarter 2010 unit costs, excluding fuel-related taxes, will increase from fourth quarter 2009 to $7.45. Our year-over-year unit cost pressures are more heavily weighted towards the first half of 2010, in particular the first quarter, due to our capacity reductions. Our first quarter 2010 available seat miles will be down in the 5% to 6% range while we expect our full-year ASMs to be roughly flat. For the full year 2010, we are projecting our ex-fuel unit cost to be up in the 5% range as a result of our flat capacity and inflationary pressures in many cost categories.We can assure you that we know this is not acceptable and adjusting our cost structure and improving our productivity to support the changes that we've made with our schedule will be one of our top priorities in 2010. We've swiftly adjusted our schedule to adapt to a higher underlying cost structure due to energy prices and a weaker demand environment. Now is the time to adjust our costs to our more flexible schedule and it is our intent to do so. That being said, it cannot be done overnight and it will take us time to build and make the necessary adjustments.With respect to our airport costs, our landing fees and other rentals on a unit basis, increased 18.5% to $0.77, primarily due to airport rate increases and that was partially offset by some favorable airport product adjustments. Based on the continuous rate inflation at various airports, which was really being driven primarily by capacity reductions, we expect our first quarter airport unit cost to exceed fourth quarter, $0.77 and we're currently estimating the first quarter 2010 airport unit costs to be in the mid-$0.80 range.Our salaries, wages and benefits increased on a unit basis to $3.66 over fourth quarter at last year, and higher wage rates accompanied by our 7.7% capacity reduction contributed to the year-over-year increase. Based on our current cost and capacity trends, we expect our first quarter 2010 salaries, wages and benefits unit cost to increase from fourth quarter's $3.66. And on a year-over-year basis, we expect the unit cost to be up in the 8% to 9% range. Our maintenance unit cost decreased 11.5% year-over-year, which was better than anticipated, primarily due to fewer-than-expected events. Based on the planned events and the reduced capacity, we expect our first quarter 2010's maintenance unit cost to be in the high $0.70 range.Turning to the balance sheet. Our liquidity remains strong. One of our main goals for 2009 was to protect our financial health and we succeeded by maintaining a healthy cash balance and investment rating and modest levels of debt. As of yesterday, we had core unrestricted cash and short-term investments of $2.4 billion. Our $600 million credit facility remains fully undrawn and available. Our leverage, including aircraft leases, is in the 45% range and we have very manageable scheduled debt maturities in 2010. For 2009, our cash flow from operations was $985 million, which was net of a $90 million increase in our fuel hedge collateral deposits. After capital spending and scheduled debt payments, we generated free cash flow of $400 million, which we used to repay our revolver.For the full-year 2010, we expect that our capital spending will be in the $600 million to $700 million range. With respect to our fleet, we ended 2009 with 537 Boeing aircraft. During the fourth quarter, we did not have any scheduled firm orders from Boeing but we reduced our fleet by four aircrafts. Our fourth quarter available seat mile capacity decreased 7.7% and our full-year capacity was down 5.1% compared to 2008. We remain very cautious with our capacity plans for 2010 and we are not planning to grow the fleet this year and expect our full-year available seat mile capacity to be roughly flat with 2009. As I mentioned earlier, our year-over-year capacity declines are weighted to the first half of the year with our largest quarterly declines planned for the first quarter. Our forecasted quarterly ASM capacity is as follows: In the first quarter, we'll will be down in the 5% range. In the second quarter, our ASMs will be down in the 1% range. The third quarter, we're currently projected to be up in the 1% range and the fourth quarter up into 2% range.As we've done successfully for the past several years, we will continue to optimize each published schedule. We have firm orders with Boeing this year for 10 700 aircraft and we have a like amount of classic lease aircraft and with expiring leases as well as the ability to retire our own traffic aircraft. We have included an updated Boeing delivery schedule in the accompanying tables to the press release issued this morning. And Marvin, with that, I think Gary and I are ready to take questions.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And we'll now take our first question from Mike Linenberg with Bank of America.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And we'll now take our first question from Mike Linenberg with Bank of America.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: With respect to the hedging, Laura, you provided that 2010 you were 50% hedged at up to $100 a barrel. The way to think about that, is there a larger portion of that hedge book, is it closer to $100, do you have a weighted average number just so when we m
componenttext: With respect to the hedging, Laura, you provided that 2010 you were 50% hedged at up to $100 a barrel. The way to think about that, is there a larger portion of that hedge book, is it closer to $100, do you have a weighted average number just so when we model depending on how oil prices move, we can come up with a number?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Mike, think of it, that's the amount that's hedged up the $100 is with protection beginning kind of in the mid-70, in the mid-70 range. So it's protection within that arena. And then it drops to 20% protection if prices are above $100 and then 40% if pric
componenttext: Mike, think of it, that's the amount that's hedged up the $100 is with protection beginning kind of in the mid-70, in the mid-70 range. So it's protection within that arena. And then it drops to 20% protection if prices are above $100 and then 40% if prices exceeding $120.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Some of the hedge's there in the money and you're getting the benefit of it now?
componenttext: Some of the hedge's there in the money and you're getting the benefit of it now?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: That is correct, which is why that hedge penalty has decreased from where were a year ago.
componenttext: That is correct, which is why that hedge penalty has decreased from where were a year ago.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: My second question is you gave us the fare mix for biz travel. You said it was right around 18%. And I want to make sure, is that 18% of revenue and what does that compare with what it was a year ago and then what is a more normal number for you? As thing
componenttext: My second question is you gave us the fare mix for biz travel. You said it was right around 18%. And I want to make sure, is that 18% of revenue and what does that compare with what it was a year ago and then what is a more normal number for you? As things get back to normal, is that somewhere in the mid-20s?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, it was answerable [ph] (36:04) in several steps. A year ago, our full fare mix was 24%. So it was somewhat about six points. That's certainly the fact that we had a 9.5 point load factor increase the storage that, [ph] (36:17) that dropped somewhat b
componenttext: Yes, it was answerable [ph] (36:04) in several steps. A year ago, our full fare mix was 24%. So it was somewhat about six points. That's certainly the fact that we had a 9.5 point load factor increase the storage that, [ph] (36:17) that dropped somewhat because so much of that gain is driven by the discretionary loser traffic. So we would expect in a record load factor to see more of a drop in line traffic. But I'd say mid-20s is probably reasonable to what we'd like it to be when we get back to more normal times.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Bill Greene with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question is from Bill Greene with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: I'm wondering, Gary, can you talk a little bit about how soon you think you would sort of ramp up the capacity growth. What are the things you're watching for? Because you used to grow quite a bit faster and you mentioned in Laura's remarks the unit cost
componenttext: I'm wondering, Gary, can you talk a little bit about how soon you think you would sort of ramp up the capacity growth. What are the things you're watching for? Because you used to grow quite a bit faster and you mentioned in Laura's remarks the unit cost pressure. So how do we think about timing by return to normal levels? And what's normal for you now?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I don't think we have anything specific beyond what we're reporting today. Laura mentioned that we're managing schedule by schedule. You know what we have been describing over the past couple of years in terms of transforming Southwest Airlines' cap
componenttext: Well, I don't think we have anything specific beyond what we're reporting today. Laura mentioned that we're managing schedule by schedule. You know what we have been describing over the past couple of years in terms of transforming Southwest Airlines' capabilities to deal with a new reality. I think about one of the new realities, of course, is much higher energy cost. And Bill, I just don't think we are there yet. So 2010 for Southwest Airlines is as you know, will probably be the highest hedged jet fuel cost for Southwest Airlines in our history. So we need to be prosperous to afford to grow. We need to be hitting our return on investment targets. I believe that we will soon hit those targets before we add to the fleet. And on the heels of -- when I saw the ATA reporting yesterday, this is the worst drop in revenues the airline industry has ever experienced. I certainly agree with that and that's the way it felt. So I don't think any of us believe that now is the time to be talking about growth. We want to grow, we'll be looking for opportunities to grow. We'd like to be bold but the risk reward will just need to balance out there, but in terms of thinking about any new opportunities. But for the time being, you should just expect that if our results are like they were in '09, we would not want to grow the fleet.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: So that'll be financially driven?
componenttext: So that'll be financially driven?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Absolutely. Now, just trying to be not quite so vague, we'll be open to acquisitions and opportunities that could unfold in an environment like this, if they unfold. But absent that, in other words, yes, we'll be looking for some confidence that our reven
componenttext: Absolutely. Now, just trying to be not quite so vague, we'll be open to acquisitions and opportunities that could unfold in an environment like this, if they unfold. But absent that, in other words, yes, we'll be looking for some confidence that our revenues are going to overcome these higher operating costs and we're not there yet.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Now you didn't mention an ability to start flying to international or near international destinations. Is that because that's not a near term thing? You just don't have the technology to get there?
componenttext: Now you didn't mention an ability to start flying to international or near international destinations. Is that because that's not a near term thing? You just don't have the technology to get there?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, yes. We had major technology implementations in 2008. We had even more major installations in 2009 and we have two big projects underway still for '10. One of those is international and Codeshare. So when that work is completed in 2010, we won't be
componenttext: Well, yes. We had major technology implementations in 2008. We had even more major installations in 2009 and we have two big projects underway still for '10. One of those is international and Codeshare. So when that work is completed in 2010, we won't be prepared yet to fly our own metal to international markets. That will be a future project and a future deliverable and something that we're interested in but it's not 2010 and probably not 2011 for that matter. Our other major priority in the near term as you recall, is the next generation Rapid Rewards program. So big effort underway in 2010 to wrap that up.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: But, Gary, correct me, wasn't the $1.5 billion you were targeting in non fare resident opportunity, doesn't that include international? Or do I have that wrong?
componenttext: But, Gary, correct me, wasn't the $1.5 billion you were targeting in non fare resident opportunity, doesn't that include international? Or do I have that wrong?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Bill, the only thing that -- going back to 2007 when we laid out our transformation strategy, it was Codeshare and international. It was not flying around international. I don't think we've ever said that we are interested in pursuing that and as time has
componenttext: Bill, the only thing that -- going back to 2007 when we laid out our transformation strategy, it was Codeshare and international. It was not flying around international. I don't think we've ever said that we are interested in pursuing that and as time has gone by, if you go from '07, '08 to '09, I think we've gotten more interested ourselves in flying international. But no, that was not part of the $1.5 billion back in 2007.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Do you have an estimate how close you are to the $1.5 billion?
componenttext: Do you have an estimate how close you are to the $1.5 billion?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, back in 2008, I thought we were more than halfway there already. And then of course, we've had a setback in 2009 with the recession. We'll kind of circle back up on that, Laura, because we had a very pleasant development in the second half of 2009.
componenttext: Well, back in 2008, I thought we were more than halfway there already. And then of course, we've had a setback in 2009 with the recession. We'll kind of circle back up on that, Laura, because we had a very pleasant development in the second half of 2009. A lot of things were working really well. So I think we'll need to reevaluate that target. The $1.5 billion relative to '07 is very realistic but the target is smooth. So energy prices are very different in '10 compared to where we thought we were going to be in '07. So $1.5 billion isn't enough. So we've got to up that target, enhance that internally.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Hunter Keay with Stifel, Nicolaus.
componenttext: Our next question is from Hunter Keay with Stifel, Nicolaus.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: How many more bags have been checked for passengers since the Bags Fly Free Campaign really started to get ramped up?
componenttext: How many more bags have been checked for passengers since the Bags Fly Free Campaign really started to get ramped up?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I don't think there's been any change in our customer behavior, except that we've seen a very significant increase in our load bags. So I think that's been the big change and I think relative to -- and of course, they were more bags coming with more
componenttext: Well, I don't think there's been any change in our customer behavior, except that we've seen a very significant increase in our load bags. So I think that's been the big change and I think relative to -- and of course, they were more bags coming with more customers. But I think that's one of the points that I would just reemphasize, that despite a very radical change in load factors, our operations have held up extraordinarily well. So we've been very, very proud of the quality of the operation all the way around. But we haven't seen any changes in customer behavior and that so the same applies to the carry-ons. We haven't seen anything remarkably different in Southwest. Other carriers -- obviously, they've had customer behavior changes but we haven't seen that in the Southwest.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: And I noticed there was a big sequential uptick in other operating expenses. I think presumably some of that is increased ad spend from the marketing of the Bags Fly Free Campaign. Can you maybe -- if it's correct or incorrect then maybe quantify it for m
componenttext: And I noticed there was a big sequential uptick in other operating expenses. I think presumably some of that is increased ad spend from the marketing of the Bags Fly Free Campaign. Can you maybe -- if it's correct or incorrect then maybe quantify it for me, the incremental ad spend?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: We definitely had increased advertising in the fourth quarter. I think it's high -- it's up about 10%. The real driver in the other operating expense increased -- how do I say -- [ph] (44:01) revenue related. So the charge cell discounts grow and as the r
componenttext: We definitely had increased advertising in the fourth quarter. I think it's high -- it's up about 10%. The real driver in the other operating expense increased -- how do I say -- [ph] (44:01) revenue related. So the charge cell discounts grow and as the revenues grow, we see the charge of discounts grow significantly. So that's really a bigger driver of the increase in other operating than advertising, which also contributed.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Garrett Chase with Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Our next question is from Garrett Chase with Barclays Capital.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: If you could elaborate on Laura, I think during your prepared remarks, you stated that the comps on RASM get tougher through the quarter and that's kind of opposite what I would think it we might but just looking at where you were, you were positive Janua
componenttext: If you could elaborate on Laura, I think during your prepared remarks, you stated that the comps on RASM get tougher through the quarter and that's kind of opposite what I would think it we might but just looking at where you were, you were positive January last year and pretty substantially negative by the time you hit March. Just wondered if you could maybe elaborate a little bit on what you're thinking there?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: I think I agree with you that we really started to see travel deteriorate in February, late January, but definitely February and March. Really the point there was just to point out that there's other factors in there and the biggest being our own capacity
componenttext: I think I agree with you that we really started to see travel deteriorate in February, late January, but definitely February and March. Really the point there was just to point out that there's other factors in there and the biggest being our own capacity reductions, the fact that we're going to have 7% ASM reduction in first quarter versus kind of 4% to 5% in the second, and not first quarter and January versus February March, will distort that. But I do agree we do, you've got some easier comps on one hand but tougher comps as a result of our capacity reductions.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Could you just -- Laura, did you say down 7% in Q1, could you just go through the months where you're going to  be on...
componenttext: Could you just -- Laura, did you say down 7% in Q1, could you just go through the months where you're going to  be on...

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: I really meant to say, Gary, down in January. We're going to be down about 7% in ASMs. February and March, our ASMs are only going to be down between 4% and 5%. So that was really the point that our own capacity adjustments have a less favorable year-over
componenttext: I really meant to say, Gary, down in January. We're going to be down about 7% in ASMs. February and March, our ASMs are only going to be down between 4% and 5%. So that was really the point that our own capacity adjustments have a less favorable year-over-year comp as we move throughout the quarter.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: But clearly, this sort of overall environment gets a lot easier just in terms of your RASM [ph] (46:13)?
componenttext: But clearly, this sort of overall environment gets a lot easier just in terms of your RASM [ph] (46:13)?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: I completely agree. I think that's fair.
componenttext: I completely agree. I think that's fair.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: You mentioned the cost issue and you said that you weren't satisfied, and these things take time. And I guess my question is could you maybe walk us through what it is about that plus five that you think with more time you can address? Can you talk about
componenttext: You mentioned the cost issue and you said that you weren't satisfied, and these things take time. And I guess my question is could you maybe walk us through what it is about that plus five that you think with more time you can address? Can you talk about sizing the cost structure to a more flexible schedule? What is it that you think you'll be able to deal with over time that isn't release feasible to tackle during the course of this year?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think if you look at what we've, Gary, add into, we've made some pretty significant adjustments in how we schedule. And you can see that we have a lot more demand in the second and third quarter, then there is in the first and fourth quarter. So w
componenttext: Well, I think if you look at what we've, Gary, add into, we've made some pretty significant adjustments in how we schedule. And you can see that we have a lot more demand in the second and third quarter, then there is in the first and fourth quarter. So we've got a little bit heavier in time waiting. And we've done those changes in the schedule over a very, very fast period of time. So I think, really, the point is it just takes time for us to adjust our operations and improve our productivity to adjust to those changes. So I don't know if there's anything else you might want to add.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: I'll just try to say it. I thought Laura said it very well. I've just tried to say it in a little bit different way to see if you don't clarify. We've had a long history of producing what, for all practical purposes, was a static schedule. And the only ch
componenttext: I'll just try to say it. I thought Laura said it very well. I've just tried to say it in a little bit different way to see if you don't clarify. We've had a long history of producing what, for all practical purposes, was a static schedule. And the only changes to our static schedule were more airplanes and more flights. Now what we are forced to do is to react to a higher energy cost, which means higher costs per trip. So you can't fly your way into lower unit costs with energy. And what you're seeing now in 2010 is the most exaggerated scheduling for us, adjusting to seasonality. So I think that's the point Laura was making is that we've really pulled down capacity in January because the demand is lower. And we are  purposely bringing it back in a more flexible way mid February, when we think demand will pick up seasonally. We've never done that before. So that's that. And then underneath that, we basically have the same staff in place in a fixed way on the ground to a lesser degree in the air, whether we have a reduced schedule in January or whether we have a full schedule in March. So we have not quite cracked that nut on how we make our cost structure a little bit more flexible, although we're determined to do that. So I don't think neither one of us is prepared to describe today what we're going to do or what our ideas are and none of it will necessary come easy. But that's the challenge and we'll just repeat, like what I said at the beginning, I think our people are more than up to that challenge. But our focus right now has been improving the customer experience and transforming Southwest's capabilities, and we are performing exceptionally well there. And we don't turn our sights on and 2010 is getting our productivity enhanced even further. If you look at our employees per aircraft, it improved yet again in 2009. So we're making progress. We just need to make more rapid progress. And I think just finally, one of the things that we're faced with here on the airports, Laura, she pieced that one out, our airport costs are going up for two reasons: One is the nominal costs are going up, which is painful and another cell. But secondly, the overall activity in the industry is going down and I know you understand all that. But that's one of our bigger cost issues in 2010 and what I describe won't address that. So we're going to have to find offsets to that very significant cost pressure that we're incurring at this point.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Dwayne Pfenningworth with Raymond James.
componenttext: Our next question is from Dwayne Pfenningworth with Raymond James.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: With regard to other revenue, it looks like on a per passenger basis, that increased sequentially to the 450 range. I'm wondering what you think the longer-term target for other revenue per passenger could approach?
componenttext: With regard to other revenue, it looks like on a per passenger basis, that increased sequentially to the 450 range. I'm wondering what you think the longer-term target for other revenue per passenger could approach?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Dwayne, I am not sure we can give you any real guidance out there. We definitely saw a nice increase in our other revenues per passenger in the fourth quarter, and we've got a lot of initiatives that we still have underway with southwest.com. We've talked
componenttext: Dwayne, I am not sure we can give you any real guidance out there. We definitely saw a nice increase in our other revenues per passenger in the fourth quarter, and we've got a lot of initiatives that we still have underway with southwest.com. We've talked about some of the things that we have to improve our cell cars and hotels and so forth. So that work is still in the plan. So we think there's a significant opportunity to increase our other revenues per passenger. I'm just not sure we're ready to give you a target yet.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: I agree. The only thing that I think that we've done some modest things on the ancillary revenue area this past year with EarlyBird, Pets, the much needed fee for unaccompanied minors. The big opportunity out in front of us is with our Rapid Rewards progr
componenttext: I agree. The only thing that I think that we've done some modest things on the ancillary revenue area this past year with EarlyBird, Pets, the much needed fee for unaccompanied minors. The big opportunity out in front of us is with our Rapid Rewards program. And we're looking for a very significant revenue contribution there. On the top of my head, Laura, I can't convert that to a per passenger target. But I can at least tell you where were the source of the increase in ancillaries on that, clearly with the frequent flyer program.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: So this quarter, for the first time in a while, total RASM grew faster than passenger RASM. Should we expect that spread to continue to increase there?
componenttext: So this quarter, for the first time in a while, total RASM grew faster than passenger RASM. Should we expect that spread to continue to increase there?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I hope that -- the freight has really lagged and it still is. It's down double digit. At least we've seen a lot better strength in the passenger side of our business, and that's pretty big piece of that whole other category. So it would be nice to s
componenttext: Well, I hope that -- the freight has really lagged and it still is. It's down double digit. At least we've seen a lot better strength in the passenger side of our business, and that's pretty big piece of that whole other category. So it would be nice to see some improvement in the economy that would drive moving of goods and hopefully, we'll get more than our fair share. I think we did a great job with our target [ph] (52:58) product. And then again, as time goes by, we're adding more and more. We've got www.southwest.com, evolutions or phases I should say, that will continue to come, that will create better opportunities for hotels, rent cars, so you should see that. And then of course, you get a frequent flyer program, it will come much later next year, early 2011. But, I think for the time being, that's probably a reasonable assumption.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Certainly, for the first, say three quarters of this year, the full-year impact of the initiatives that we talked about EarlyBird, Pets, but we're going to see some big gains year-over-year and then hopefully by that time, a lot of these new initiati
componenttext: Yes. Certainly, for the first, say three quarters of this year, the full-year impact of the initiatives that we talked about EarlyBird, Pets, but we're going to see some big gains year-over-year and then hopefully by that time, a lot of these new initiatives that we have should be rolling out, too. So we should continue to see those per passenger growth.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: And I think there's leverage here too. In other words, our mantra is to win more customers. And we think and we continue to believe we have opportunities to win more business customers, as well as the subset of that. More customers will drive more stuff.
componenttext: And I think there's leverage here too. In other words, our mantra is to win more customers. And we think and we continue to believe we have opportunities to win more business customers, as well as the subset of that. More customers will drive more stuff. And I definitely think that we're in a -- we've got very strong momentum with our brand and there's every reason for us to believe it will continue to drive more ancillary revenues because for a lot of reasons, we get more customers.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Laura, in terms of your x-fuel CASM, I apologize if you already said this, but given your flat sort of capacity plan for the year, how should we think about x-fuel CASM relative to the 5% growth that you're seeing in the first quarter?
componenttext: Laura, in terms of your x-fuel CASM, I apologize if you already said this, but given your flat sort of capacity plan for the year, how should we think about x-fuel CASM relative to the 5% growth that you're seeing in the first quarter?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the guidance, Dwayne, is that for the full year of 2010, we expect that our x-fuel CASM will be up in the 5% range. For the first quarter of 2010, we're going to have more -- really the first half of 2010, our unit cost pressures and x-fuel
componenttext: Well, I think the guidance, Dwayne, is that for the full year of 2010, we expect that our x-fuel CASM will be up in the 5% range. For the first quarter of 2010, we're going to have more -- really the first half of 2010, our unit cost pressures and x-fuel cost will be greater than the system average because of the capacity reductions. So the first quarter, I think what I've mentioned was that we expect our first quarter x-fuel unit costs to exceed our fourth quarter 2009 unit costs, which was 7.45%. So that's going to be a higher increase in the first quarter than the 5% that we expect for the full year.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Helane Becker with Jesup & Lamont.
componenttext: Our next question is from Helane Becker with Jesup & Lamont.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Gary, I just these two questions. One, can you say in terms of -- actually, talk about the experience in LaGuardia and how successful that's been so far? And if there's been share shift away from flight [ph] (55:49) and if that hurt operations, if at all?
componenttext: Gary, I just these two questions. One, can you say in terms of -- actually, talk about the experience in LaGuardia and how successful that's been so far? And if there's been share shift away from flight [ph] (55:49) and if that hurt operations, if at all? And my second question is at one point in the past, you guys had talked about plan of taking fare increases, $2, $3 here and there, maybe once a year in May timeframe. And I think last year, you may have had a few other fare increases during the year. Can you just talk about how you're thinking about that going forward?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: I'll take that in reverse. Yes, the days of the annual fare increases are long gone. We've been -- especially in 2008 with the obvious pressure that we've had in energy costs that we had a number of aggressive fare increases that year. And it worked very
componenttext: I'll take that in reverse. Yes, the days of the annual fare increases are long gone. We've been -- especially in 2008 with the obvious pressure that we've had in energy costs that we had a number of aggressive fare increases that year. And it worked very well until we slammed into November, really in the fourth quarter of '08. Even in 2009, our normal mantra is it's really hard to price yourself out of a recession. But even in 2009, we've had a series of -- they've been broad but very tactical, I think very wise efforts to increase fares. I think a fair evaluation of the success of those that most of those worked well. Obviously, the first fare increase has a better chance of driving revenue than the last one, because they sort of compound. But now, we're in a mood where -- again, back to the comment i made earlier, we must adjust as an industry and as an airline to higher operating costs. We're doing that as aggressively as we dare. And the results of all of our various actions over the last couple of years, I'm very pleased with. I think the evidence is very strong that our folks are doing a great job there. We'll continue to look for fare increase opportunities, because we're not hitting our profit targets yet. And we are expecting to have cost hurdles to overcome. So we're trying to do that in a way that we maintain our Low Fare Brand. And I think again, that's one of the reasons why the Bags Fly Free has become such a meaningful weapon in our arsenal. It's just another way for us to demonstrate to customers that we do stand for overall low fares, and it's something that our competitors can't match. And at the same time, we can keep the rest of our fare structure relatively low, even though we will be increasing it overtime. On the New York question, no share shift that's visible to us at all from ice-led sales [ph] (58:36). I don't see there's any cannibalization there at all. The LaGuardia operation for Southwest is quite small, it's eight round trips. The on-time performance with those flights has been slightly below average but certainly nothing that we have been concerned about. Obviously, we're doing our best to make sure that if there are some operational integrity issues there that we don't affect the rest of the system. And again, we have the best on-time performance year in 2009 that we've had in many years even with the additions of some challenging places like that. The business for us in New York LaGuardia has been spectacular. It's been a huge contributor right off the bat. I don't think any of us are shocked at that because we did have a very conservative schedule. We have far more demand for Southwest into New York than what we can satisfy with any flights. And the revenue performance certainly provides evidence to that.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: So does it make sense to add more capacity there or how are you thinking in that?
componenttext: So does it make sense to add more capacity there or how are you thinking in that?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: I would sort of answer that right now as a hypothetical because we physically cannot. We can't get another gate, we don't have access to another slot, I can't tell you how we would. If we could get more gates, more slots, we would definitely want more fli
componenttext: I would sort of answer that right now as a hypothetical because we physically cannot. We can't get another gate, we don't have access to another slot, I can't tell you how we would. If we could get more gates, more slots, we would definitely want more flights, but I don't think we have an unlimited appetite here. Denver is going to go 144 flights in August. We're not thinking about LaGuardia in the same way.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: At one point in your past, the average trip length I think for flights, assuming like 75 minutes. So the incidence of people that would want to check bags, what's that number now?
componenttext: At one point in your past, the average trip length I think for flights, assuming like 75 minutes. So the incidence of people that would want to check bags, what's that number now?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, our average flight distance is around 650 miles. If memory serves, I don't think of it in time so much, it's less than two hours I think. So your memory is good on the 75, although you have to go back quite a ways. I think we have a very challenging
componenttext: Well, our average flight distance is around 650 miles. If memory serves, I don't think of it in time so much, it's less than two hours I think. So your memory is good on the 75, although you have to go back quite a ways. I think we have a very challenging operation. We don't huff and smoke. But unlike other competitors where they connect, they have a large bag connecting complexes at just a couple of places. We connect all over our system. And I don't know that we know how many bags we check per customer compared to the industry. That's not a statistic we've been able to get our hands on, but we check a lot of bags now. I can't remember. Helane, if you go back 20 years ago when we were much short in a row, how that would compare. But we certainly carry a bunch of them now.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Will Randow. [Citigroup]
componenttext: Our next question is from Will Randow. [Citigroup]

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Can you discuss how we should think about your ability to grow capacity if industry revenue improves by the 10% currently factored in the consensus and what if we come above that? I mean how flexible can you be?
componenttext: Can you discuss how we should think about your ability to grow capacity if industry revenue improves by the 10% currently factored in the consensus and what if we come above that? I mean how flexible can you be?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: What is the 10%?
componenttext: What is the 10%?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of North America industry revenue, if you do a roll up of consensus, where the street is looking for a 10% for this year? So I mean when you think about that, if we hit that number, a better number than that, how flexible are you to grow capacity
componenttext: In terms of North America industry revenue, if you do a roll up of consensus, where the street is looking for a 10% for this year? So I mean when you think about that, if we hit that number, a better number than that, how flexible are you to grow capacity?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: I think we're very flexible to a point. So for example, in 2010, we could probably squeeze in a number of ways, we can hold on to some airplanes. We can go to the used market. We could probably fly our -- even the airplanes that aren't in service, we coul
componenttext: I think we're very flexible to a point. So for example, in 2010, we could probably squeeze in a number of ways, we can hold on to some airplanes. We can go to the used market. We could probably fly our -- even the airplanes that aren't in service, we could probably fly them a little bit more. So there's a number of techniques we could use in the near term. In the longer-term, I think there's even more flexibility. The problem of course in this business is if we're forced today to make decisions about 2012, it's just a track sheet, so vis-a-vis your questions. But no, I think we have plenty of flexibility to add capacity at least to a degree in the near term if that's what we want to do. Now, we're published out through August 13. So even that, we could jam in more airplanes and more flights in that time period if we want to. But it would be a little painful and it wouldn't be optimized, so I think the best thing for us is to be able to add more flights after August 13 and have it all integrated on what we're working on right now.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: And then in terms of bag fees, obviously, your competitors recently raised about $5 or so. What kind of incremental share gain do you think that opportunity offers you? And then secondly, I know you've thought about the potential the bag fee kind of as a
componenttext: And then in terms of bag fees, obviously, your competitors recently raised about $5 or so. What kind of incremental share gain do you think that opportunity offers you? And then secondly, I know you've thought about the potential the bag fee kind of as a hedge against on a dollar plus per barrel oil, I guess how should we think about that as well as other ancillary opportunities to protect you from higher oil? Obviously, you have one of the best hedging portfolios but the other opportunities?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that you should cheer on our competitors to charge really high bag fees. And you'll continue to see record load factors at Southwest Airlines. So again, I would just repeat that we reduced capacity in the fourth quarter 8% and at the same ti
componenttext: Well, I think that you should cheer on our competitors to charge really high bag fees. And you'll continue to see record load factors at Southwest Airlines. So again, I would just repeat that we reduced capacity in the fourth quarter 8% and at the same time, we grew our passengers. We grew our RPMs and we achieved their record load factors. So it is very clear that we're seeing a share shift. Those are the facts. My guess is that and our folks have made several different calculations on this, but it also points to a roughly 1% share shift in the domestic market U.S. which is huge, somewhere between $1.5 billion and $1 billion worth of additional customers. And that's what we're trying to do. We're trying to win more customers and we would love to sell them more stuff. So we've got all that work underway as well. But yes, we're not going to be charging for bags. So I hope they charge $100 a bag, that would be terrific. We'll have 100% load factors, it will be great.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Lastly, Laura, in terms of when you look at your balance sheet and capital structure, your net debt to EBITDA, leverage is improving, free cash flows turned positive as compared to a lot of airlines. When you think about limited maturities, what are kind
componenttext: Lastly, Laura, in terms of when you look at your balance sheet and capital structure, your net debt to EBITDA, leverage is improving, free cash flows turned positive as compared to a lot of airlines. When you think about limited maturities, what are kind of your ratings goals as well as the initiatives you may take on the balance sheet as we think about the next year or two?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we certainly haven't changed our views in wanting a strong balance sheet and investment-grade rating. And I think the reason of doing that was it came pretty clear as what we see what we lived through over the last year and a half. So our leverage i
componenttext: Well, we certainly haven't changed our views in wanting a strong balance sheet and investment-grade rating. And I think the reason of doing that was it came pretty clear as what we see what we lived through over the last year and a half. So our leverage is our around 35%. I think we're pretty comfortable in the 40%, 45% range. And we certainly want to maintain our investment-grade credit ratings. We haven't changed our goal there.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of what are the initiatives you want to take in the capital structure next year?
componenttext: In terms of what are the initiatives you want to take in the capital structure next year?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: I think we have -- the biggest initiative we've taken and I'd say over the last couple of years is to reduce our capital spending, which has really allowed us to -- we raised a lot of money last year because we wanted to increase our cash balance but as w
componenttext: I think we have -- the biggest initiative we've taken and I'd say over the last couple of years is to reduce our capital spending, which has really allowed us to -- we raised a lot of money last year because we wanted to increase our cash balance but as we look into 2010, we had very modest capital spending and very modest debt retirements, we don't anticipate that we have a need to go back to the market and raise additional money and increase our interest expense and all those things. So that's really our goals to kind of shore up the balance sheet in the near future. In terms of the longer-term things, what we might do with free cash flow I think it's still a little early to tell, because we've got to see what happens with the economy and when we want to really start growing again and it's helpful. But those will be the types of things that I can assure you, we will be very focused on.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: We have time for one last question and our last question will come from Mr. Dan Mackenzie with Next Generation Equity Research.
componenttext: We have time for one last question and our last question will come from Mr. Dan Mackenzie with Next Generation Equity Research.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Following up on the revenue initiatives underway, I'm not sure if you're ready to put a number around what they're worth. But I'm wondering if you can provide some additional color about how investors should think about the materiality of the initiatives
componenttext: Following up on the revenue initiatives underway, I'm not sure if you're ready to put a number around what they're worth. But I'm wondering if you can provide some additional color about how investors should think about the materiality of the initiatives or perhaps even the timing?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, as we were here on the call, we just kind of penciled out what we've done so far and what remains. It's relative to Bill Green's earlier question about where are we with the $1.5 billion target. And I think with what you all know, when you kind of p
componenttext: Well, as we were here on the call, we just kind of penciled out what we've done so far and what remains. It's relative to Bill Green's earlier question about where are we with the $1.5 billion target. And I think with what you all know, when you kind of put these things together, what we've been reporting all year long, I think that we'll probably -- with new things that have been added, Business Select, EarlyBird, Pets, just a long list of things. We're probably close to $1 billion in incremental revenues, we're just that stuffed. And I don't think it's a leap at all to believe that what we have teed up for 2010 and 2011 will easily fill out the $1.5 billion. I think the only other point that I would make is that we all recognize that our target is now more than $1.5 billion. And we know that and of course, you all should know that. But again, Dan, I think the things that are in front of us, our international approach here, which should provide a very meaningful contribution. It's a no-brainer that it will add revenue. And we know we have a very powerful domestic network and we have a very strong brand. We will definitely add customers and revenues once we get those up and running. And then secondly, it is our next-generation Rapid Rewards program, it is very straightforward. In addition to the ambitious goal of desiring more loyalty, we're just looking at getting our current members to be a little stickier within so that they'll fly us more and encourage more of them to use the Southwest credit card. So it's not a pie-in-the-sky thing here that we're talking. I think we've got a very meaningful revenue opportunity, certainly relative to our peer group that we've not realized yet. And I think we know why and we intend to close that gap.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: And I guess as my follow-up question here, I wonder if you can provide a little bit more granularity on where the demand is coming from. Would you characterize it as being driven primarily by business or leisure? I know that on the website when you book y
componenttext: And I guess as my follow-up question here, I wonder if you can provide a little bit more granularity on where the demand is coming from. Would you characterize it as being driven primarily by business or leisure? I know that on the website when you book your ticket, one of the questions that Southwest prompts everybody buying the ticket is the trip is for business or for leisure. So I wonder if there's any some further perspective or some color you can provide with respect to that?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: We've been very open about the typical decline in business travel demand. That has occurred as expected in the recession. It was worse than what we thought. It hasn't gotten worse since summertime, if anything, it may have gotten better. But we're certain
componenttext: We've been very open about the typical decline in business travel demand. That has occurred as expected in the recession. It was worse than what we thought. It hasn't gotten worse since summertime, if anything, it may have gotten better. But we're certainly not seeing a large return of business traffic nor are we predicting that for 2010. So the strength in our revenues, I think is pretty easily demonstrated. It's not the short-haul markets, it's the medium, the longer-haul markets. It's more of the leisure flavor to it. And again, in addition to all the things that we've added like EarlyBird, we're just getting more customers and they're more leisure customers. The domestic market isn't growing in the U.S. but Southwest is growing even without adding capacity. So that's the share shift that we're talking about and with the Low Fare Brand in a recessionary environment where people are trying to spend their money more wisely, I just think we're getting a real nice craze here. And when business travel does pick up, I think you're going to see a very nice boost in our revenues yet again. So we're doing very well on the revenue front.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Dan, I think from a regional basis, there was no sector of the country that didn't see an improvement. So it was pretty broad. Certainly, we've got certain areas where we've got more short-haul traffic and where we have a bigger short-haul markets, and th
componenttext: Dan, I think from a regional basis, there was no sector of the country that didn't see an improvement. So it was pretty broad. Certainly, we've got certain areas where we've got more short-haul traffic and where we have a bigger short-haul markets, and those don't show quite as good improvement as some of the destinations that have a little more long-haul and medium-haul focus. But the improvement was across the board.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010

componenttext: At this time, I'd like to turn the call back over for any additional or closing remarks.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
