headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Welcome to the Southwest Airlines Second Quarter 2010 Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] We have on the call today Gary Kelly, Southwest's Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Laura Wright, the company's Senior Vice President Finance
componenttext:
Welcome to the Southwest Airlines Second Quarter 2010 Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] We have on the call today Gary Kelly, Southwest's Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Laura Wright, the company's Senior Vice President Finance and Chief Financial Officer.
Before we get started, please be advised that this call will include forward-looking statements. Because these statements are based on the company's current intent, expectations and projections, they are not guarantees of future performance, and a variety of factors could cause actual results to differ materially.
This call will also include references to non-GAAP results. Therefore, please see the company's financial results press release in the Investor Relations section of our website at southwest.com for further information regarding forward-looking statements and for a reconciliation of non-GAAP results to GAAP results. 
At this time, I'd like to turn the call over to Gary Kelly for opening remarks. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Marvin, and thank you all for joining us this morning for our second quarter results. We had a very strong performance. We're very pleased with the profit for the quarter. x items, $216 million, which is $0.29 a share. Each of those represents mor
componenttext:
Thanks, Marvin, and thank you all for joining us this morning for our second quarter results. We had a very strong performance. We're very pleased with the profit for the quarter. x items, $216 million, which is $0.29 a share. Each of those represents more than a tripling of our year-ago results.
Of course, all the credit goes to our people. They've done a marvelous job getting Southwest Airlines to this point. They certainly performed extraordinarily well in the quarter. They've managed a tremendous amount of change, not just over last couple of years, but for the last decade. So I'm very, very proud of them and very proud of these results.
We continued to set a number of company records relating to revenues during the quarter. We placed first in the domestic airline industry in two very important categories. First of all, revenue growth of 21.1% is the best in the industry, domestically, and that comes on a slightly down capacity growth at Southwest Airlines. And that means that we also placed first in the domestic industry in terms of year-over-year unit revenue growth, at almost 22%.
Our passenger counts were up. Our traffic was up. Very strong yield performance in the quarter. Our yields were up over 17%. Had a record load factor of 79.3%, which was up 2.3 points compared to '09. And Laura's going to spend quite a bit of time talking about revenues as well, because it's a revenue story. That's what drove our earnings growth. And a number of factors are involved, of course, driving our revenue growth. All that led to the second-best quarterly profit in our history, second only to the second quarter of 2006.
So from this point forward, beginning in the third quarter, our year-over-year comps changed a great deal. Last year was significantly off our normal trends. Based on our current July results so far, and the bookings for the rest of the quarter, we don't expect any significant deviation from normal years seasonal trends; just our continued strong revenue production.
Talking a little bit about Panama City Beach, we added to our route system in May. We're off to a great start there. Customers' response has been tremendous. And I do want to say that we really appreciate all the support we've gotten from the St. Joe Company, but also the airport and the entire community. And again, thanks for helping us to get off to a good start, and hopefully we're doing a small part to help the community as well. And I've been there, and I can report that the beaches look great, by the way. So everyone should don their swimsuits and get down there ASAP on a Southwest flight. 
I'll turn it over to Laura to take us through the quarter.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Gary, and good morning, everyone. Our second quarter GAAP net income was $112 million or $0.15 per share. Excluding special items totaling a net of $104 million relating to mark-to-market and other items associated with FAS 133, our second quar
componenttext:
Thank you, Gary, and good morning, everyone. Our second quarter GAAP net income was $112 million or $0.15 per share. Excluding special items totaling a net of $104 million relating to mark-to-market and other items associated with FAS 133, our second quarter net income was $216 million or $0.29 per share; a significant improvement over second quarter last year's earnings of $59 million or $0.08 per share.
Our second quarter operating income, excluding special items, was $414 million, resulting in an operating margin of 13%. And our pretax income, excluding special items, was $350 million, resulting in an 11% pretax margin.
Overall, it was a very strong second quarter performance, the second best in our history. And I'd like to congratulate our employees on these results and thank them for their hard work and their outstanding customer service.
The revenue momentum that started in the second half of last year continued into the second quarter, producing another record revenue performance. Our passenger revenues increased over $500 million to $3 billion.  And our other revenues increased nearly 50%, or $38 million compared to last year. With both record loads and record passenger yields, we also had a record 20.7% year-over-year improvement in our passenger unit revenues within the industry and domestic revenue results. 
More importantly, compared to the second quarter of 2008, our unit revenues grew 14%. Our total revenues of $5.8 billion for the first six months of 2010 represents a revenue increase of over $1 billion from our revenues for the first six months of 2007, while our capacity for the first half of this year is approximately 1% less than the first half of 2007.
The plan that we set forth in 2007 to grow our revenues is producing results, even despite the still-weak economic environment and even with business travel well below pre-downturn levels. Our revenue strength in the quarter was driven by our revenue initiatives, fewer fare sales and strong overall consumer demand. The yield improvement strengthened throughout the quarter, with April and May up 16% and June up 19%, resulting in an all-time record 17.3% growth in RPM yields. 
Business travel demand continued to strengthen during the quarter, and our full-fare mix was just under 20%, up almost two points from second quarter of last year and down less than a point from the first quarter of 2010. The sequential decline of under one point was better than historical sequential trends, suggesting some stabilization in our full-fare demand. And in our short-haul markets, we saw more than a three-point year-over-year improvement in our second quarter full-fare mix. We're very encouraged by the improvement in our business trends, but we also recognize that business travel has not fully recovered.
We have strong demand for our Business Select products, with 24% more Business Select passengers than a year ago, producing $24 million in incremental revenue, up from $18 million in the second quarter of last year. We also had strong demand from our EarlyBird product, generating $23 million in EarlyBird revenues, compared to $17 million in the first quarter of this year and $13 million in the fourth quarter of '09.
We have not seen any noticeable impact to our Business Select revenues from the introduction of our EarlyBird product. Our EarlyBird passengers continue to increase as a percentage of total passengers, while our Business Select passengers are above the EarlyBird introduction levels.
Our Wright Amendment revenues were $55 million in the quarter, compared to $37 million second quarter a year ago. And overall, we are very encouraged by our passenger revenue trends.
Month-to-date, our July passenger unit revenues are up in the 17% range from the respective year-ago period. And bookings thus far for August and September also look strong. Based on revenue and booking trends thus far, we're currently expecting another significant year-over-year improvement in our third quarter passenger unit revenues, but at a lower year-over-year rate, and experienced in the second quarter. As the current quarter and the remainder of the year progress, our year-over-year comparisons become more difficult due to our industry-leading improvement in revenue trends in the second half of last year.
Our freight revenues increased 15.8% to $33 million, primarily due to higher average rates. And we expect that our third quarter freight revenues will be comparable to the second quarter. Our other revenues increased almost 50% to $119 million, due to our fall 2009 revenue initiatives. As I mentioned earlier, we generated about $23 million in EarlyBird revenues, and we also generated approximately $13 million in revenues from our Pet Fares, Unaccompanied Minors service charges and excess heavy bag fees. 
We expect another year-over-year increase in our other revenues in the third quarter, but at a much lower rate than experienced in the second quarter, due to fewer charters anticipated and also to reaching the anniversary on the introduction of some of our revenue initiatives.
As a reminder, in the third quarter of last year, we generated about $12 million in revenues from these same revenue initiatives.
Turning to our cost performance. Our second quarter operating expenses, excluding special items, increased 13%, which results in a 13% unit cost increase. Although we had non-fuel cost pressure contributing to our overall unit cost increase, the most significant pressure came from higher fuel costs. Our economic fuel cost increased 32.4% to $2.37 per gallon, which was slightly better than expected, due to lower crude oil prices offset by higher heating oil crack spreads and jet differentials.
Based on the third quarter fuel hedge provided in our press release this morning, and the July 26 forward curve, our guidance for the third quarter economic fuel price is in the $2.40 per gallon range.  This estimate includes fuel taxes, but excludes fuel hedging premiums. We're currently estimating a slightly higher third quarter fuel price in the second quarter, due to higher jet diff as we move into the hurricane season, and a slightly higher fuel hedge penalty.
Our premium costs associated with our third quarter fuel hedge, which are recorded below the line in other gains and losses, are estimated to be in the $36 million range. And based on market prices as of July 26, and our hedge for the second half of this year, we're estimating our 2010 economic fuel price, including taxes, will be in the $2.40 per gallon range.
We have factored the various price points and percentages of our current hedge position, plus the impact from the hedges that were unwound in 2008, into our fuel price guidance and the sensitivities that we will provide in the Form 10-Q.
We continue to actively manage our hedge portfolio with the philosophy of protecting the business against catastrophic energy prices, and we've included our current hedge positions for 2011 and beyond in this morning's press release.
Excluding fuel and special items, our second quarter costs increased 6.4% on a unit basis. Although still up more than we would like, our second quarter non-fuel cost performance was better than anticipated, primarily due to deferral of advertising cost and a refund of excess security fees paid to the TSA. Regarding our advertising spend, we chose to defer about $8 million originally planned for the second quarter to later in the year, including some to the third quarter.
Higher profit sharing in 401(k) accounted for approximately three points of the 6.4% CASM x fuel increase. We accrued $62 million in profit sharing and $49 million in 401(k) for a total benefit to our employees of $110 million this quarter.
Our revenue-related charges, which are primarily charge-sell [ph] (14:19) discounts, accounted for another point of the non-fuel CASM increase. And, of course, we're always happy to talk about higher profit sharing and revenue-related charges. But that being said, we also continue to have inflationary cost pressure, most notably in our airport and our labor costs. Based on these continued cost pressures, we currently expect our third quarter non-fuel unit cost to increase from third quarter 2009 $7.11, and we currently expect that increase to be in the 6% range year-over-year, which is similar to what we saw in the second quarter.
Although it's reasonable to expect that our third quarter year-over-year unit cost pressure would ease, due to the modest capacity increase that we have planned for the third quarter, keep in mind that the $18 million security refund and the deferral of the advertising spend benefited our second quarter non-fuel unit cost by about 1 points. 
For the full year of 2010, we are expecting our unit costs, excluding fuel and special items, to increase in the 6% to 7% range compared to last year. This estimate is higher than the 5% estimate we provided at the beginning of this year, and is being driven by increased profit sharing and revenue-related expenses.
Before I move on to the balance sheet, I'd like to quickly talk about our labor and airport costs. As expected, our labor costs increased 9.8% on a unit basis versus last year, primarily due to wage rate inflation and profit sharing. And based on current trends, we expect our third quarter labor unit costs to be comparable to second quarter's $3.71. 
With respect to airport costs, our landing fees and other rentals unit costs increased 15.7% year-over-year, primarily due to airport rate increases and fewer favorable airport audit adjustments this year. Based on the continued rate inflation at various airports, we're expecting our third quarter airport unit costs to fall in the mid-$0.80 range.
Now moving on to the balance sheet and cash flow. We currently have $3.4 billion in core unrestricted cash and short-term investments, and our $600 million credit facility remains fully undrawn and available. Our leverage, including aircraft leases, is forecasted to be in the low-40% range by year end. We generated about $400 million in free cash flow in the second quarter, with $540 million of cash flow from operations and capital spending of $159 million.
Year-to-date, our cash flow from operations are over $900 million, and we generated over $600 million in free cash flow. Based on current trends, and our projected 2010 capital spending of less than $600 million, we currently expect to generate free cash flow for the year.
We're currently working on our strategic plan for the next decade, and capital planning is certainly a significant part of that exercise. We recently updated our fleet plan with Boeing, which I will go over shortly, without any material change to our total future capital spending.
In regards to our fleet and our capacity plan, during the quarter, we acquired three 700s from Boeing, and we ended the quarter with the fleet of 544 aircrafts. 
We're well underway in evaluating our long-term fleet plans. And as part of that planning, we've decided to slightly accelerate the retirement of our classic fleet. Accordingly, we worked with Boeing to update our future from orders and options schedules, with no net change to our fleet plans. We converted six purchase rights to options, and exercised 25 options for firm orders from 2011 through 2016. We've included the updated Boeing delivery schedules as an accompanying table to this morning's press release. 
We do not intend to significantly grow the fleet until our financial goals are achieved or in sight. Further, we're planning for flat capacity this year. Third quarter ASMs will be about 2% year-over-year. And in the fourth quarter, they're going to be up approximately 4% year-over-year.
For 2011, we're projecting a modest capacity increase and flat fleet. And keep in mind that the modest increase in our 2011 capacity will be heavier-weighted towards the first half of the year as a function of our 2010 flight schedule adjustments.
As always, we'll continue to closely monitor demand and remain prepared to adjust our flight schedules accordingly. 
And Marvin, with that overview, Gary and I are ready to take questions.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And we'll go to our first question from Michael Linenberg with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And we'll go to our first question from Michael Linenberg with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I want to actually talk about revenue, Gary. And I think back over the years, over the many years where you had the conversation, we've talked about the sensitivity of your passenger base, where you would move fares up a few dollars, and it was always the
componenttext: I want to actually talk about revenue, Gary. And I think back over the years, over the many years where you had the conversation, we've talked about the sensitivity of your passenger base, where you would move fares up a few dollars, and it was always the proverbial family of four not taking the trip. I then look at this quarter, and I see your one-way fares go from $110 or $112 to $132. I mean, these are high by historical levels for Southwest. And then I look at where the unemployment rate is in the U.S. It's close to a 30-year high at 10%. We know that the consumer is constrained. Discretionary spending is just tight. And yet, even then, it's not coming on the business side. I mean, you've seen some modest improvement. So the question is, is it that your network has evolved, your breadth of your network today? You're in a lot of business markets, you're the biggest domestic carrier, plus the fact that you have a more advanced Revenue Management System. I mean, is it easier today for Southwest to raise fares? Or has your passenger base changed? Has their price elasticity of demand come down? I mean, I know this is a very long and winded question here, but when I look at these numbers, I've never seen fare improvement of this magnitude, given a very challenging macro backdrop.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: So Michael, I take that's not a complaint.
componenttext: So Michael, I take that's not a complaint.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Its a high-quality problem to have. And I'm just wondering, what are you guys seeing? I mean, there's definitely been some evolution here.
componenttext: Its a high-quality problem to have. And I'm just wondering, what are you guys seeing? I mean, there's definitely been some evolution here.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we'd have to -- gosh, we started working together in 1991 or '92, right?
componenttext: Well, we'd have to -- gosh, we started working together in 1991 or '92, right?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Thats right. So it's been a few cycles.
componenttext: Thats right. So it's been a few cycles.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: You'd have to pick your time slice here, but over a 20-year time horizon, of course, much has changed. But I was just glancing at the earnings release and the average length of the passenger haul is now 883 miles. That's at least part of the standards. Bu
componenttext: You'd have to pick your time slice here, but over a 20-year time horizon, of course, much has changed. But I was just glancing at the earnings release and the average length of the passenger haul is now 883 miles. That's at least part of the standards. But there's a lot going on here, Mike. And Laura referenced in her remarks the strategy that we put forth in 2007, and we'll want to summarize this better for the investment community this fall, and just show you where we are vis--vis that plan. But the point is, a lot has changed. Now, we have argued and can demonstrate to you that there's a significant market share shift that's taking place over the last several years. You know that costs are up. We've already admitted, years ago, that we were going to have to find a way to adjust our fare structure upwards to deal with higher costs, and we're doing that. So I think you've got a combination of shifting out of short-haul markets into longer-haul markets, which is helping. You've got the fact that Southwest has offered more choice to people who want more service and are willing to pay for it. And Laura pointed out a 24% increase in Business Select as an example. We've seen weeks where it's up 30% and 40%. So we're finding opportunities to bring new products and services to the market that people will pay us. And, of course, the other material change just over the last 12 months is EarlyBird. There was concern when we introduced EarlyBird that it would cannibalize Business Select, and obviously, Laura's reporting that there's no evidence of that. So there's a few pieces in there. In terms of just our over overall fares though, getting to our core fare structure, our revenue management has evolved dramatically in 36 months. They are much more skilled at setting inventory levels at various prices and not giving away any more than they have to. And so I think there's a significant benefit associated with that. And then the other thing that you've seen from an overall schedule perspective, if you took 100% of our flights three years ago and you trimmed out the flights that weren't very good, which is what we've done, and instead you came back with a flight schedule that was more powerful, which is what we've done, then that's a way to ring out revenues as well. So in the old days, Mike, we would have flights at the end of the day that might have 20 people on them. And you're not getting very good yields on them either. Those days are gone. And so now you have a much more condensed flight schedule with much higher load factors, many more itineraries being published, a few more connecting customers are on board. So we've created better demand for our own product in addition to the fact that we're taking share from our competitors.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Duane Pfennigwerth with Raymond James.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Duane Pfennigwerth with Raymond James.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Just wondering if you could provide a little more detail about your second half seasonality commentary. Because it seems like the years you've referenced actually imply a pretty wide range. Specifically, I think 2006, 3Q RASM was down about 8% sequentiall
componenttext: Just wondering if you could provide a little more detail about your second half seasonality commentary. Because it seems like the years you've referenced actually imply a pretty wide range. Specifically, I think 2006, 3Q RASM was down about 8% sequentially, and 2008 it was actually up modestly. So can you just help us with how we should interpret that?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Duane. I think if we look at 3Q versus 2Q -- or let's just even talk about July, since we've kind of given where we are for July. Typically, July PRASM compared to what you see in June is flat to down a couple of points year-over-year. So if you real
componenttext: Yes, Duane. I think if we look at 3Q versus 2Q -- or let's just even talk about July, since we've kind of given where we are for July. Typically, July PRASM compared to what you see in June is flat to down a couple of points year-over-year. So if you really start looking at sequential trends versus year-over-year comps, our July revenue results are actually slightly exceeding what we'd normally see on the average for month-to-month. So I think that's really what we're really trying to talk about in terms of seasonal trends versus year-over-year trends, that the results we're seeing in July and the bookings that we have thus far for August and September, relative to the nominal results that we had in the second quarter, make sense to us. So we really haven't seen any drop-off in the momentum that we built up in the second quarter.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And, Duane, I would just add to what Laura said by saying it is rare that you see an increase in revenue performance, in order words, RASM performance, in the third quarter compared to the second quarter. It is very normal for us to have a peak in the yea
componenttext: And, Duane, I would just add to what Laura said by saying it is rare that you see an increase in revenue performance, in order words, RASM performance, in the third quarter compared to the second quarter. It is very normal for us to have a peak in the year in the second quarter. And that's what we're expecting this year. Normally, if you average some of those years that you were describing -- I think all we were trying to point in the earnings release is that 2009 is really off. It is really off of normal trends. The fourth quarter was the best quarter of the year. And it's hard to go back in history and find a year like that. Normally, I would say -- this is just Gary talking -- is we're normally down RASM 3Q versus Q2 in the 2%- to 3%-range. And some years, June is the best month of the year. Some years, July is the best month of the year. And it's possible that July -- I think this is the point Laura's really trying to make, is that when we look at the strength of our revenues coming into the third quarter, they are very good. And, in fact, July may very well be the best month this year. September is still September, and will not match an April or May. So that's what you're typically contending with seasonally.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And just wondering, in terms of sort of no-net fleet growth, how we should think about new markets. How many new markets a year for Southwest? And should we be reading anything into the Panama Cities, the Greenvilles and the Charlestons? Is that sort of a
componenttext: And just wondering, in terms of sort of no-net fleet growth, how we should think about new markets. How many new markets a year for Southwest? And should we be reading anything into the Panama Cities, the Greenvilles and the Charlestons? Is that sort of a new sort of attractive target for Southwest?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we've done a variety of cities, historically, of course. Some years we had big cities, and some years we've added smaller cities. And that's true in the 80s, 90s and the past 10 years. So I wouldn't read anything into it other than that's what we've
componenttext: Well, we've done a variety of cities, historically, of course. Some years we had big cities, and some years we've added smaller cities. And that's true in the 80s, 90s and the past 10 years. So I wouldn't read anything into it other than that's what we've chosen to do in 2010 and 2011. The flat fleet, I wouldn't take literally. I'm sure will be up a few units or down a few units from time to time. It's just more of the direction that we want you all to know that we don't have any plans to materially increase the fleet. In 2011, I don't think we can add any more new cities other than the two in South Carolina unless we make a change to our fleet plans. So I think that answers your question for next year. For 2012, really all we're telling you all at this point about 2012 is that we are not currently committed to any change in the fleet for 2012. On the other hand, we've made no plans for 2012. So if we are going to add new cities, those are decisions that will be out in front of us, as well as how we fund those new cities in terms of airplanes. So we're not telling you a prediction that we will not grow the fleet in 2012. It's just, at this point, our baseline is no change in the fleet. I'd love for us to add a couple of cities in '12, and we certainly have a long list that we're contemplating. And we're working a lot of those opportunities. So there's a chicken-and-egg question here to some degree, but at least thatll give you some guidance for the near term, which would be 2011.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Garrett Chase with Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Garrett Chase with Barclays Capital.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Just a quick one on the July RASM. Just curious if there's anything we should be thinking of that's quirky about July. And I understand you've given a lot of thoughts on the revenue outlook, but is there something that we might not know that is in the com
componenttext: Just a quick one on the July RASM. Just curious if there's anything we should be thinking of that's quirky about July. And I understand you've given a lot of thoughts on the revenue outlook, but is there something that we might not know that is in the comp that makes it a little tougher than, say, August might be, just in terms of year-on-year change?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I think when you look at last year, Gary, our July, we really started turning our results in the second half of last year. So our July RASM last year versus what we saw in June was a significant improvement, and again, far above what would have been expec
componenttext: I think when you look at last year, Gary, our July, we really started turning our results in the second half of last year. So our July RASM last year versus what we saw in June was a significant improvement, and again, far above what would have been expected sequentially. So the year-over-year comps are definitely difficult there, but really there's nothing. If you look at July versus June, just on the nominal of what you should expect from a RASM basis, our trends for July show that we're outperforming what we would normally expect sequentially from June to July.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And, Gary, let me just offer up a couple up a hints here. And I agree with Laura. I don't see anything odd about July at all, or June, for that matter. In other words, I think they both look normal. As I said earlier, some years, June is better; some year
componenttext: And, Gary, let me just offer up a couple up a hints here. And I agree with Laura. I don't see anything odd about July at all, or June, for that matter. In other words, I think they both look normal. As I said earlier, some years, June is better; some years, July is better. I'd have to think about the Fourth of July and what impact that holiday timing might have on those months. But our RASM in '09 from 2Q to 3Q was up five points. And that just doesn't happen. So if you buy my normal trend of 2Q to 3Q is down two, that's a seven-point swing. So that's what I would urge you to look at and think about. And, of course, then based on that, the July comps, the June fits pretty well. And again, it's because last years July was off-trend relative to last year's June. It's a comp issue more than it is a seasonality issue. Because this year's June to July is going to be something. Laura will have to tell you what she wants to tell you on this year's July, but I guess you've got to wait a couple of days to hear those results. But this year's July looks really good.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then how are you measuring your success? I mean, when you think about generating business traffic, Biz Select [Business Select] might be a way to think about that. There are probably some other ways that you're thinking about it. I'm wondering,
componenttext: Okay. And then how are you measuring your success? I mean, when you think about generating business traffic, Biz Select [Business Select] might be a way to think about that. There are probably some other ways that you're thinking about it. I'm wondering, what metrics are your guys focusing on? Because obviously, business traffic could show up in any fare class. What are you focusing on to see if you're really getting that incremental revenue onto your network? And could you share with us maybe some of the metrics as you look at them?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I think we can. And I think that's something that we're going to want to continue to refine as we go forward. And just in terms of the way we're reporting to you all now, just in terms of the recovery of business travel. We look at it in a variety of ways
componenttext: I think we can. And I think that's something that we're going to want to continue to refine as we go forward. And just in terms of the way we're reporting to you all now, just in terms of the recovery of business travel. We look at it in a variety of ways. Fare class gives you some insight, but certainly not a complete picture. We look at bookings within the travel date. We have corporate accounts, just like everybody else does. That's less than 10% of our business. Or if we look at those accounts, the business is up year-over-year in the third quarter. Gosh, what would you say, Laura?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I think traffic's up in the 20 -- passenger up 25 and revenues are up probably 40. A significant increase in the corporate account.
componenttext: I think traffic's up in the 20 -- passenger up 25 and revenues are up probably 40. A significant increase in the corporate account.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. And again, a minority of our business. And not even the majority of our business travelers, but at least some indication that we're seeing some strengthening there. She's reported Business Select. And then the other thing I think that Laura mentioned
componenttext: Yes. And again, a minority of our business. And not even the majority of our business travelers, but at least some indication that we're seeing some strengthening there. She's reported Business Select. And then the other thing I think that Laura mentioned is the short-haul markets. It's the short-haul markets where we find most of our business travelers. The only way we know they're on business is we ask them. We do continuous surveys. And our short-haul markets are continuing to lag the overall system in terms of recovery, although they are recovering at a pretty nice rate. So now, if I understand where you're headed with your question, we want to drive more business travel on Southwest. I think the share shift that we're seeing right now is mostly on the consumer side. But prospectively, we'll be rolling out Wi-Fi on the fleet, we'll be upgrading our Frequent Flyer program. We've obviously added some products like Business Select that will meet the needs of business travelers. But we'll have a bigger push and a stronger message for business travel over the course of the next 12 months.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I just want to correct my corporate accounts. We're actually up over 30% in tax and over 50% in revenues from a year ago, second quarter.
componenttext: I just want to correct my corporate accounts. We're actually up over 30% in tax and over 50% in revenues from a year ago, second quarter.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from Bill Greene with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question will come from Bill Greene with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Gary, I hate to be the dead horse in this, but I want to just make sure I understand it, because it kind of suggests the seasonality comments that we have to lower RASM expectations. And I thought Laura said July is seasonally -- it's sort of stronger-tha
componenttext: Gary, I hate to be the dead horse in this, but I want to just make sure I understand it, because it kind of suggests the seasonality comments that we have to lower RASM expectations. And I thought Laura said July is seasonally -- it's sort of stronger-than-expected seasonality. But I thought you just said it wasn't. And I'm only trying to get it because it suggests August and September are below trend. And I was just hoping you could just clarify it, because I think I'm not clear on exactly what it is.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I was vague, so that's fair. I'm going to let Laura answer. But what I did not say is that it was weaker than seasonally. But I'll let Laura give you an idea of how strong it is seasonally.
componenttext: Well, I was vague, so that's fair. I'm going to let Laura answer. But what I did not say is that it was weaker than seasonally. But I'll let Laura give you an idea of how strong it is seasonally.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Bill, if you look at normal sequential trends from June to July, they're usually flat to -- Garys point, sometimes June's a little better, sometimes Julys a little better because of the timing of Fourth of July. But usually, July versus June, it's f
componenttext: Bill, if you look at normal sequential trends from June to July, they're usually flat to -- Garys point, sometimes June's a little better, sometimes Julys a little better because of the timing of Fourth of July. But usually, July versus June, it's flat to down a percent or so. And that's nominal RASM, not year-over-year increase. So if you look at the year-to-date trends that we disclosed for July, which is up 17%, and again, last year we were up significantly in July versus June, and compare that to where we were in June, we're not out of line seasonally. In fact, I'd say we're going to look a little bit better than what our normal June to July trends would indicate.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. So yes, so then August and September would need to be below trend to get normal seasonality for the quarter?
componenttext: Okay. So yes, so then August and September would need to be below trend to get normal seasonality for the quarter?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, it just depends on what you call normal. So I think Duane was pointing out that some years, the 3Q is up little bit, and some years it's down 8%. And the average is sort of down for the quarter 2% to 3%. That's the best guidance I can give you. And
componenttext: Well, it just depends on what you call normal. So I think Duane was pointing out that some years, the 3Q is up little bit, and some years it's down 8%. And the average is sort of down for the quarter 2% to 3%. That's the best guidance I can give you. And the other is just that quarterly hint. And it's too close to call July at this point. And I know I did say that it's possible that July could be the best month this year. So I wouldn't conclude from that if July is better than June that, that means that August and September are weak. I wouldnt conclude that all.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: That's not at all what we were trying to say.
componenttext: That's not at all what we were trying to say.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. So if I can turn to balance sheet, almost $3.5 billion in cash, no significant growth plans next two years or so. Should we think about a much bigger buyback? You didn't do any in this quarter, one-time dividend. What do we do with this? Because whe
componenttext: Okay. So if I can turn to balance sheet, almost $3.5 billion in cash, no significant growth plans next two years or so. Should we think about a much bigger buyback? You didn't do any in this quarter, one-time dividend. What do we do with this? Because when we think about your ROIC targets, it would seem that, that could be very supportive of it. It could get you there sooner. But maybe that's not a part of how you mean to get there. Maybe it needs to be organic.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, we're in a good situation, Bill, because we are generating free cash flow. And, as you know, that wasnt top of mind a year ago. But, first of all, we haven't changed our philosophy of wanting a strong balance sheet, and we're saving
componenttext: Well, first of all, we're in a good situation, Bill, because we are generating free cash flow. And, as you know, that wasnt top of mind a year ago. But, first of all, we haven't changed our philosophy of wanting a strong balance sheet, and we're saving our investment grade rating. Our leverage is forecast to be back to 40% by the end of the year. And, as you know, we've reduced our capital spending. So what we're doing right now is we're exploring all of our options which, as you know, are limited. We've looked at our fleet plan. We're thinking about protection on fuel prices. Of course, we've got a steady share repurchase. Debt retirements, we've got about $400 million that matures at the end of 2011 and about $300 million, I think, in the first quarter of 2012. We've got to be prepared for opportunities that present themselves, and we're also kind of looking at this financial reform legislation. So through all that, we're working with our board right now. We haven't made any decisions on what we want to do with the excess cash. As you know, our focus is on maximizing shareholder value. So I think you can expect us to come back to you at some point in the future with an answer to that question. But we have not made a decision yet.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Hunter Keay with Stifel, Nicolaus.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Hunter Keay with Stifel, Nicolaus.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I appreciate you guys publicly setting a 50% ROIC target. I'm wondering if you could actually calculate -- or share with us how you calculate that metric, and maybe tell us what it was on a trailing 12-month basis. Because I'm getting about maybe 6.5% for
componenttext: I appreciate you guys publicly setting a 50% ROIC target. I'm wondering if you could actually calculate -- or share with us how you calculate that metric, and maybe tell us what it was on a trailing 12-month basis. Because I'm getting about maybe 6.5% for 2010, maybe about 4% LTM, which tells me that future growth could be really far off, if that's actually the hurdle that you're going to want to hit. But I might be calculating it differently than you guys are. Can you maybe share how you look at it?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Absolutely. So if you just look at rolling 12-month basis through June 30, we're around 7%, which is obviously well off our 15% target. But that includes the back half of 2009. So with our increased earnings outlook for the second half of this year, we do
componenttext: Absolutely. So if you just look at rolling 12-month basis through June 30, we're around 7%, which is obviously well off our 15% target. But that includes the back half of 2009. So with our increased earnings outlook for the second half of this year, we do expect that our ROIC for the 12 months ended 2010 will be significantly better than that 7%. So we are making some really good progress towards that 15% target, although we don't expect that we're going to be there in terms of how we publish it. It is on our website, in our IR tab, but our numerator is our non-GAAP operating income less the gains and losses from the trend value of hedges. And then we also neutralized the P&L impact of leasing aircraft versus purchasing them. And the denominator is the average of our debt in our equity net of the balance, other comprehensive income and hedging and effectiveness, plus the net present value of future aircraft rents. But Marcie and I [ph] (43:22) would be happy to walk you through those calculations, and you can look them up on the website also.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And just backing into it, I guess the net income target, Laura, to hit 15% is roughly $850 million [ph] (43:36). So somewhere in the eights, Hunter, is another way, just a rule of thumb, at least for the purposes of this morning. We're making good progres
componenttext: And just backing into it, I guess the net income target, Laura, to hit 15% is roughly $850 million [ph] (43:36). So somewhere in the eights, Hunter, is another way, just a rule of thumb, at least for the purposes of this morning. We're making good progress, but we've got a ways to go. I think if you then extrapolate from that, if this is a revenue generation solution, then we probably need about $500 million-ish of annual revenues to hit that target.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: It looks like maybe you -- this might just be sort of fine-tuning of the schedule, but it looks like maybe you tacked on a little bit of ASMs in the fourth quarter relative to where you were in April? Is there some stage length in there? Are you adding so
componenttext: It looks like maybe you -- this might just be sort of fine-tuning of the schedule, but it looks like maybe you tacked on a little bit of ASMs in the fourth quarter relative to where you were in April? Is there some stage length in there? Are you adding some frequencies? Is this utilization? Or is there really not much of a change over the last few months?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I saw Laura's comparison of what we said last to where we are. I don't know that it's anything material. I think we had a forecast before, now we've come back with an actual schedule. So it's the same number of airplanes. So somehow, we've eeked out a lit
componenttext: I saw Laura's comparison of what we said last to where we are. I don't know that it's anything material. I think we had a forecast before, now we've come back with an actual schedule. So it's the same number of airplanes. So somehow, we've eeked out a little bit more utilization that what we really thought initially. But there's really nothing of any significance that I can think of that would account for that variance.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I agree.
componenttext: I agree.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: So no notable fleet frequency additions in, say, business markets or anything that comes to mind or anything like that?
componenttext: So no notable fleet frequency additions in, say, business markets or anything that comes to mind or anything like that?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: No. And, again, the schedule's been out there for a while. So it's published through January 7. That's just the way the math added up, I guess.
componenttext: No. And, again, the schedule's been out there for a while. So it's published through January 7. That's just the way the math added up, I guess.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Jamie Baker with JPMorgan.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Jamie Baker with JPMorgan.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Based on what seemed to emerge from Farnborough, it really sounds as if Boeing doesn't have much interest, at least near term, in re-engining the 73. And I'm just wondering if that potentially influences the fleet plans. I've personally just wondered if t
componenttext: Based on what seemed to emerge from Farnborough, it really sounds as if Boeing doesn't have much interest, at least near term, in re-engining the 73. And I'm just wondering if that potentially influences the fleet plans. I've personally just wondered if the decision to stop growing might be based, on some part, on wanting to wait for the re-engined planes. So if it turns out that plane isn't coming after all, could you settle for the existing model and resume growth? I'm just wondering how that factors in, if at all, to the fleet plan.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, Jamie, I understand your question. Very fair question. We're under non-disclosure, as you would guess, with Boeing in terms of what their plans are. So those Boeing-type questions, obviously, have to be directed to them. So if you'll just permit me
componenttext: Well, Jamie, I understand your question. Very fair question. We're under non-disclosure, as you would guess, with Boeing in terms of what their plans are. So those Boeing-type questions, obviously, have to be directed to them. So if you'll just permit me not to offer you much color here and just say that our near-term fleet plans, certainly '10, '11 and '12, are not dependent upon the question that you pose. However, we have enormous interest in the topic that you raised. And if I could just say that we're engaged deeply with Boeing on the retirement of our classics, on the replacement of the classics, on the re-engining opportunity, and then complete next-generation airplane opportunities. So we're deep into that with Boeing. I'll defer to them to tell you where they are in that process. We are clearly -- first of all, we're huge fans of Boeing. They are great partners with us, have been for four decades. And, secondly, we are in need of a more efficient, cost-effective aircraft. And that is our mission. And we're obviously very hopeful that Boeing can meet our needs there going forward.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And, secondly, simply because it hasn't come up yet on the call, U.S. Airway margins were healthy in the quarter. Delta's margins were healthy as well. United and Continental continue to march down the aisle. I'm just curious if anything you're seei
componenttext: Okay. And, secondly, simply because it hasn't come up yet on the call, U.S. Airway margins were healthy in the quarter. Delta's margins were healthy as well. United and Continental continue to march down the aisle. I'm just curious if anything you're seeing going on around you changes your perspective on consolidation. Southwest has thrived in a fragmented industry in the past, and I'm just curious if a potentially consolidated industry affects your game plan going forward at all?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Jamie, I don't think so. We've had pretty massive consolidation this past decade, assuming that the United, Continental deal goes through. We serve 69 cities, soon to be 71 next year, with the introduction of South Carolina to our route system. There are
componenttext: Jamie, I don't think so. We've had pretty massive consolidation this past decade, assuming that the United, Continental deal goes through. We serve 69 cities, soon to be 71 next year, with the introduction of South Carolina to our route system. There are many more cities that we would like to serve in the United States and, of course, we are pondering whether we want to prepare ourselves to fly international. And I would expect the decision on that sometime this year. So we want to continue to grow, is my point. We think weve got the cost structure and the customer experience package, and the people to do that. I think consolidation works in our favor in that regard. And it certainly has to this point. I think just the fact that we can demonstrate to you that we're winning customers right now and significant revenue gains as a share of the domestic market gives us a lot of encouragement going forward. So we're going to continue to invest in our own customer experience. And if consolidation continues, again, I think that, that -- I just don't see that, that's a negative for us. And in that regard, no, I don't think that changes our strategy here.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Dan McKenzie with Hudson Securities.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Dan McKenzie with Hudson Securities.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I know Southwest has a number of products under construction, but I wanted to follow-up on the Rapid Rewards comment, Gary. How should investors think about the revenue contribution from a more sophisticated Rewards program? And then, I guess I'm wonderin
componenttext: I know Southwest has a number of products under construction, but I wanted to follow-up on the Rapid Rewards comment, Gary. How should investors think about the revenue contribution from a more sophisticated Rewards program? And then, I guess I'm wondering if you can help us understand what percent of the wallet spend you're getting from your most loyal passengers? And then potentially, the revenue opportunity here from the wallet that's being left on the table?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think I can give you some color there. I think Laura and I have not provided a lot of specific details at this point. But more information, obviously, is coming on that when we get ready to launch that program. But I think the headlines are pretty
componenttext: Well, I think I can give you some color there. I think Laura and I have not provided a lot of specific details at this point. But more information, obviously, is coming on that when we get ready to launch that program. But I think the headlines are pretty straightforward. We don't get our fair share of frequent flyers relative to our seat share, if you will. The frequent flyers that we have, we don't get our fair share of their flights. And then of the frequent flyers that we have, we also don't get our fair share of credit cards. So then, of course, one has to understand, Well, what do you mean by fair share? And is there truly an opportunity there? So we've delved into that. We believe that there is a very significant opportunity for us to win more business customers, win more flights from the customers that we get, and then get a whole bunch more Southwest Visa Credit Cards in wallets out there. The combined value of all that is gigantic. The value of just the Credit Cards, quite frankly, is a very, very large number. But admittedly, and I think this is why Laura and I have always been reluctant to share any targeted numbers, is they're all speculative. And whenever you're talking about getting a market share change, that may take some time to build. So I think the easiest penetration from a revenue generation will be with the credit card, and that's what we really hung our business case on. But when we've surveyed business customers over the last decade, the single biggest point they've made with us is they want a different Frequent Flyer program. Single biggest issue. And we believe them, so we've been in design and construction for some time now, and looking forward to having that project wrapped up this year and then launched next year. So it's very exciting for us. We're obviously hopeful that we can make it a game-changer. But you couple that, again, with some of the other amenities that we're bringing forward, most notably wireless in the cabin, I think we're going to have a very, very compelling sales pitch for business travelers. We already get a whole bunch of business travelers, so it's not like we're starting from scratch there. We just think we can get more.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I guess, in terms of the Wi-Fi on board, Im wondering if you can just share, give us a little more specificity on sort of the timing of when that would be implemented. And then, I guess in terms of the timing of these other revenue initiatives, with re
componenttext: I guess, in terms of the Wi-Fi on board, Im wondering if you can just share, give us a little more specificity on sort of the timing of when that would be implemented. And then, I guess in terms of the timing of these other revenue initiatives, with respect to the Rewards program or the Credit Card, is that something that we could start seeing phase in, in 2011? Or is there some IT or infrastructure challenges or hurdles that you have to overcome first before you can implement those kinds of things?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, let me just talk about Row 44, or the Wi-Fi first. I wouldn't say that we're relaxed about this. We're working on this effort. We have various certifications that we have to sort through in terms of installing new equipment on the fleet. We have, in
componenttext: Well, let me just talk about Row 44, or the Wi-Fi first. I wouldn't say that we're relaxed about this. We're working on this effort. We have various certifications that we have to sort through in terms of installing new equipment on the fleet. We have, in essence -- from that perspective, we've got a couple of different fleet types. We've got the next-gen equipment, we've got classics. So we're in that process, and it's been slower than I would like. On the other hand, as you know, the take rate among customers on this product has been slow to take off, so I don't think we're missing out on anything yet. But our target is still to have the fleet implemented in the 2013 timeframe. And I'm very comfortable with that. Again, I think this is an investment for the future. And in the meantime, our overall customer experience, I think, is performing very, very well. And I'm sorry, Dan, I forgot your second question.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, just whether there was infrastructure impediments or IT impediments to implementing the kind of more sophisticated Credit Card or Rapid Rewards programs sooner rather than later?
componenttext: Yes, just whether there was infrastructure impediments or IT impediments to implementing the kind of more sophisticated Credit Card or Rapid Rewards programs sooner rather than later?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: It's in full build and development and we've been working on it for a couple of years. But it's made great progress and we expect to launch it, with the technology enabled to do that.
componenttext: It's in full build and development and we've been working on it for a couple of years. But it's made great progress and we expect to launch it, with the technology enabled to do that.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: It is from scratch, my friend, and custom-built for Southwest for our unique design. And as Laura just said, and as I pointed out earlier, that construction is on track and scheduled to end this year. And then we'll collect ourselves and train all of our
componenttext: It is from scratch, my friend, and custom-built for Southwest for our unique design. And as Laura just said, and as I pointed out earlier, that construction is on track and scheduled to end this year. And then we'll collect ourselves and train all of our Southwest warriors, and launch this sometime in 2011. And that date has not been shared yet.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: We have time for one more question, so we'll go with our last question from Glenn Engel from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: We have time for one more question, so we'll go with our last question from Glenn Engel from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: I'm going to ask about cost. So you've made the schedules more variable, and that's been very successful at getting the RASM up, but it's also pushed the cost up. What are you doing to make your cost structure more variable? And what do you need to get fr
componenttext: I'm going to ask about cost. So you've made the schedules more variable, and that's been very successful at getting the RASM up, but it's also pushed the cost up. What are you doing to make your cost structure more variable? And what do you need to get from your work force? What changes do you need to get from them to be able to get your cost to be more variable?

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, that's the problem. And I don't know that we have all the answers yet. But we're very mindful of the challenge there. We've made very dramatic schedule changes for this company. Frequently, over the last several years, admittedly, it is very difficu
componenttext: Well, that's the problem. And I don't know that we have all the answers yet. But we're very mindful of the challenge there. We've made very dramatic schedule changes for this company. Frequently, over the last several years, admittedly, it is very difficult for our operation to adjust to that. So it's just another reason for me to praise our people and how hard they've worked, and how well they've done. There is definitely a cost penalty that we need to go in there and try to extract. One of the things that we've been waiting for, Glenn, is some stability. In other words, to try to attack the cost question and then to come back with yet another radical schedule change sort of renders some of that work worthless. So we do seem to be getting into more stability. We might actually -- and I'm sure what's happening here in the fourth quarter is we're adding a few frequencies back in, which will certainly help that cost question. I'm not at all satisfied, in fact, with the quality of our flight schedule. In other words, while it's been good for revenue production, we've actually taken some of the convenient flight times out from a customer perspective and even a competitive prospective. And so our desire is to be able to add capacity back here with the existing fleet in a way that satisfies both. It's revenue positive, and it also helps on the cost side. Otherwise, well be looking at making sure that we take full advantage of the variability and of staffing that is available to us. We have not taken full advantage of that at this point. So we've got some -- I wouldn't call that a structural constraint, but it's just more of an operating style change that we're going to need to be making. And, as I said, we're in the midst of pursuing that. That's a fancy way of saying we might want to use more part-time employment in certain areas of the company in the future, as compared to what we've done historically.

headline: Southwest Airlines Co., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-29-2010
